meanings.def: thick, stiff paper; a piece of this for writing on
examples: a piece of card
The model of the building was made of card.
Each person wrote their question on a card.

meanings.def: a piece of stiff paper that is folded in the middle and has a picture on the front of it, used for sending somebody a message with your good wishes, an invitation, etc.
examples: a birthday/get-well/good luck card
Everyone at work signed a card for her.
When they got engaged I sent them a card.

meanings.def: a postcard (= a card used for sending messages by post without an envelope, especially one that has a picture on one side)
examples: Did you get my card from Italy?

meanings.def: a small piece of stiff paper or plastic with information on it, especially information about somebody’s identity
examples: a membership card
an appointment card
She got her first library card at the age of seven.
a set of free recipe cards

meanings.def: a business card (= a small card printed with somebody's name and details of their job and company)
examples: Here's my card if you need to contact me again.

meanings.def: a small card with your name on it that you leave with somebody after, or instead of, a formal visit
a small piece of plastic, especially one given by a bank or shop, used for buying things or obtaining money
examples: I put the meal on (= paid for it using) my card.
Can I pay with a card?
Thieves used her cards to go on a spending spree.
Contact the bank and cancel all your cards.
He had a wallet full of plastic cards.

meanings.def: any one of a set of 52 cards with numbers and pictures printed on one side, which are used to play various card game
examples: (British English) a pack of cards
(especially North American English) a deck of cards
Each player in turn must play a card.

meanings.def: a game or games in which playing cards are used
examples: Who wants to play cards?
I've never been very good at cards.
Let's have a game of cards.
She won £20 at cards.

meanings.def: a small device containing an electronic circuit that is part of a computer or added to it, enabling it to perform particular functions
examples: a printed circuit card
a memory card
a graphics/sound/video card

meanings.def: an unusual or funny person
a list of all the races at a particular race meeting (= a series of horse races)
a machine or tool used for cleaning and combing wool or cotton before it is spun
something that gives somebody an advantage over other people in a particular situation
you are unlikely to succeed because the conditions are not good for you
you are likely to succeed because the conditions are good and you have an advantage
to be told to leave a job
to make somebody leave their job
to have an idea, a plan, etc. that will give you an advantage in a particular situation and that you keep secret until it is needed
to be able to control a particular situation because you have an advantage over other people
to keep your ideas, plans, etc. secret
to tell somebody honestly what your plans, ideas, etc. are
likely to happen
examples: The merger has been on the cards for some time now.

meanings.def: to mention a particular subject, idea or quality in order to gain an advantage
examples: He accused his opponent of playing the immigration card during the campaign.

meanings.def: to deal successfully with a particular situation so that you achieve some advantage or something that you want
examples: If you play your cards right, the job could be yours when she leaves.

meanings.def: to make your plans or intentions known

idioms.def: something that gives somebody an advantage over other people in a particular situation

idioms.idiom: the cards/odds are stacked against you
idioms.def: you are unlikely to succeed because the conditions are not good for you

idioms.idiom: the cards/odds are stacked in your favour
idioms.def: you are likely to succeed because the conditions are good and you have an advantage
to be told to leave a job
to make somebody leave their job

idioms.idiom: have a card up your sleeve
idioms.def: to have an idea, a plan, etc. that will give you an advantage in a particular situation and that you keep secret until it is needed
to be able to control a particular situation because you have an advantage over other people

idioms.idiom: hold/keep/play your cards close to your chest
idioms.def: to keep your ideas, plans, etc. secret

idioms.idiom: lay/put your cards on the table
idioms.def: to tell somebody honestly what your plans, ideas, etc. are

examples: The merger has been on the cards for some time now.

idioms.def: to mention a particular subject, idea or quality in order to gain an advantage
examples: He accused his opponent of playing the immigration card during the campaign.

idioms.def: to deal successfully with a particular situation so that you achieve some advantage or something that you want
examples: If you play your cards right, the job could be yours when she leaves.

idioms.def: to make your plans or intentions known

meanings.def: to clean wool using a wire instrument
to ask a person to show their identity card, especially as a means of checking how old they are, for example if they want to buy alcohol
